title: Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis
diagnosis_topic: Infantile hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle causing gastric outlet obstruction
setup_script: A 6-week-old firstborn male presents with projectile, nonbilious vomiting after feeds for the past 3 days. He remains hungry after vomiting and has lost weight. On exam, he appears mildly dehydrated.

dynamic_flow.reply: HR 160 bpm, RR 40/min, Temp 37 °C; signs of mild dehydration (sunken fontanelle, decreased urine output).
Progressive nonbilious vomiting occurring soon after each feed; baby demands feeding immediately after vomiting.
Olive-shaped mobile mass in the right upper quadrant and visible peristaltic waves moving left to right after feeding.
Hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with chloride 88 mEq/L and CO₂ 33 mEq/L.
Pyloric muscle thickness 4 mm and length 18 mm confirming hypertrophic pylorus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV fluids and corrects electrolytes
dynamic_flow.reply: Start isotonic fluids with added potassium after urine output established; clinical status improves.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays correction and proceeds to OR immediately
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient has increased risk of postoperative apnea and complications.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places nasogastric tube and keeps NPO
dynamic_flow.reply: Stomach is decompressed while dehydration is corrected.
Surgical plan for Ramstedt pyloromyotomy after correction of electrolytes and hydration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about nonoperative management
dynamic_flow.reply: There is no role for medical therapy; surgery is definitive.
Oral feeds resume 6 hours after surgery, starting with small glucose solutions then advancing to formula/breast milk.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: No additional anomalies detected on general exam.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about postoperative complications
dynamic_flow.reply: Small risk of mucosal perforation or incomplete myotomy intraoperatively; rare recurrence.
Parents are reassured that prognosis after pyloromyotomy is excellent, with normal growth expected.
Infant can be discharged once feeding well, tolerating oral intake, and with stable electrolytes.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of classic presentation of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
Assessment of dehydration and electrolyte disturbances
Use of ultrasound to confirm diagnosis
Preoperative correction of metabolic alkalosis prior to pyloromyotomy
Safe perioperative planning including NPO, NG tube, and fluids
Postoperative feeding protocol and parental counseling
